text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- President Glafcos Clerides condemns incidents at the British bases in which Greek Cypriots stormed a police compound and freed two detainees on Monday.

- Outgoing United Nations envoy on Cyprus Han Sung-joo expressed disappointment at the progress of proximity talks between the two sides, though UN chief Kofi Annan still hopes for direct talks in June.
- President Clerides "unreservedly condemned" Monday's violence at the British bases.
- Employers call on trade unions to moderate their pay demands.
- The Employers and Industrialists Federation sees the economy improving.
- More than 50 applications for prospecting metals, including gold, have been made to the Mines Department.
- The government wants to privatise fishing shelters.
- Goodwill gestures are being discussed to boost the climate of UN proximity talks between the two sides, while the government sees their implementation linked to progress on issues of substance.

- The resumption of direct talks between the two sides is considered a given fact. Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash seeks to clarify the status of Turkish Cypriots during the talks and Nicosia links the adoption of goodwill measures to progress on issues of substance.
- The Britons revive the colonial days. They have installed armoured personnel carriers, roadblocks and soldiers armed to the teeth at Episkopi following Monday's incidents.
